attributes.title: A New King Of Toys Has Risen
summary: Hasbro is now selling more toys than Mattel.
While some toys are losing steam compared to electronic games, Hasbro has a winning recipe.
The Toys”R”Us saga isn’t a concern.
attributes.disclosure:
Analyst’s Disclosure: I am/we are long HAS. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article.

Seeking Alpha's Disclosure: Past performance is no guarantee of future results. No recommendation or advice is being given as to whether any investment is suitable for a particular investor. attributes.content:
While Mattel (MAT) is drowning as Barbie forgot to take its swimming lesson and Toys”R”, not so much “us” anymore, there is a champion rising. A new king of toys has risen. Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) is now selling more toys than Mattel and this is a trend that is not going to stop. Hasbro has built a strong business model with their brands, multiple partnerships and digital games. The new toy king has a great army to defend its position!

Understanding The Business

Hasbro is a classic toy manufacturer. What differentiates HAS from other toy companies is that it has developed a strong expertise in producing toys for others, notably Disney (DIS). Over the years, Hasbro has developed several popular brands with kids:

Source: Hasbro Fact Sheet

It is also the company behind Disney Princess, Marvel and Star Wars toys. As management is very well aware, kids enjoy playing on their PS4 or tablets more than playing with classic action figures. Hasbro has entered digital games with the acquisition of Backflip Studios (mobile game) and Boulder Media (animation studio). It can also count on a partnership with Activision Blizzard (ATVI) to stay up-to-date in the gaming world.

An Eye On The Latest Quarter

Non-GAAP EPS of $2.30, up by +40%, beat estimates by $0.50. Revenue of $1.6B, down by -1.8%, missed estimates by $120M. Dividend of $0.63/share, +11% increase.

What the CEO Said

“Hasbro’s global team’s execution of our Brand Blueprint drove revenue gains in Franchise Brands, Hasbro Gaming and Emerging Brands, including immersive brand experiences across consumer products and digital gaming. In the fourth quarter, Hasbro Franchise Brand revenues increased 11%. However, overall consumer demand slowed in November and December both for the industry and for Hasbro. Looking ahead, our innovative lines are supported by robust storytelling and digital initiatives that position us well for 2018 and beyond.”

What I Say

Hasbro remains a very strong company, but the years of surprising growth may seem behind them. After all, there is a limit to the number of Star Wars action figures and Frozen princesses you can sell in a year. Its partner brands remain a strong segment, but will show smaller growth going forward (was -10% during last quarter). Nonetheless, HAS remains a strong dividend grower showing +13% CAGR over the past decade.

Growth Vectors

Source: Ycharts

Don’t get fooled by the earnings drop as this includes a major charge of $297M due to the new tax reform. In fact, EPS jumped by 40% last quarter and it is up by 22% for the full year.

You may think that classic toys are dying after we saw what is happening with Mattel and Toys”R”Us, but fear not; Hasbro's business is doing very well. In fact, its franchise brands continues to be a growth vector for the company.

Source: HAS Q4 investor presentation

As mentioned in my previous comment, the impressive success Hasbro had with Disney products over the past couple of years make sales difficult to be beat year after year. Even with a slowdown in this segment, I consider the division to be a growth vector for the future. Disney has built a never-ending content universe where new movies will out come each year. Therefore, new toys will be designed and sold by Hasbro. There will be ups and downs, but nobody gets tired of princesses and the force!

As the middle class is rising among emerging markets, chances are classic toys will be in demand in the upcoming years. Children are all dreaming of those characters and will be happy to have their own action figures at home.

Finally, the company has a history of growing through smart acquisitions. The company could benefit from Mattel’s position of weakness to make an offer and dominate the toy industry across the world. It could also expand further into the digital world with more acquisitions.

Dividend Growth Perspective

After taking a pause with its dividend growth policy in 2009, Hasbro has positioned itself as a super-powered dividend grower. In 2018, HAS will celebrate its 9th consecutive year with a dividend raise. This makes it 1 year away from making the elite Dividend Achievers list. The Dividend Achievers Index refers to all public companies that have successfully increased their dividend payments for at least ten consecutive years. At the time of writing this article, there were 265 companies that achieved this milestone. You can get the complete list of Dividend Achievers with comprehensive metrics here.

Source: Ycharts

On top of providing a steady dividend payment, management is also aggressively increasing it. The company shows a 9.51% dividend CAGR over the past 5 years and rewarded shareholders once again with an 11% this quarter.

Source: Ycharts

As the company benefits from many tailwinds and both payout ratios are well under control, shareholders can sleep on both ears. In fact, I expect double-digit dividend growth for many years to come.

Potential Downsides

Hasbro may be done with the incredible growth Disney products have generated over the past decade. The overall excitement around those toys is not the same anymore. This doesn’t mean there will be no growth from this segment, but I don’t expect double-digit growth anymore. Hasbro will have to continue searching for additional contracts to keep up the same pace.

Also, a more important switch toward digital gaming and toys will be important to insure the business sustainability over the long haul. Classic toys will eventually fade as digital ones are taking over.

Finally, Toy”R”Us's financial challenges will not affect the company too much as it represents about 9% of its sales. However, this could give additional negotiation power to other retailers such as Walmart (WMT) and Target (TGT). Those retailers represent a very important part of HAS sales on U.S. soil.

Valuation

When you ignore the special items charged to reduce HAS EPS, the stock doesn’t look that expensive after all. In fact, considering the rest of the market, HAS may be trading at a discount!

Source: Ycharts

I’ve updated my dividend discount model calculations to reflect the company’s latest generous increase. I continue to believe the company can achieve a double-digit dividend growth rate for the upcoming decade. This leaves us with Hasbro trading at a very interesting price right now.

Please read the Dividend Discount Model limitations to fully understand my calculations.

Final Thought

HAS went through its fair share of challenges in 2017. The retail industry is having problems, MAT going down (and inviting investors to get rid of the other players at the same time) and finally the tax reform. While the market was booming, Hasbro was going sideways. The stock is currently attractively priced and shareholders will continue to enjoy a strong dividend growth doubled with a constant share buy-back program.

Seriously, if you made it this far, it’s because you liked what you read. Don’t be a stranger; leave a comment and tell me what you think! I’m asking you one more thing; click on the “follow” button (it’s orange, you can’t miss it!) and you will get notified each time I write a great piece like this one.

Disclaimer: I do hold HAS in my DividendStocksRock portfolios.

Additional disclosure: The opinions and the strategies of the author are not intended to ever be a recommendation to buy or sell a security. The strategy the author uses has worked for him and it is for you to decide if it could benefit your financial future. Please remember to do your own research and know your risk tolerance.
attributes.twitContent: $HAS - A New King Of Toys Has Risen. https://seekingalpha.com/article/4147049-new-king-of-toys-risen?source=tweet
attributes.innerMarketing: Many investors focus on dividend yield or dividend history. I respectfully think they’re making a mistake. While both metrics are important, aiming at companies that have and show the ability to continue raising their dividend by high single-digit to double-digit numbers will make your portfolio outperform others. When a company pushes its dividend so fast, it’s because it is also growing their revenues and earnings. Isn’t this the fundamental of investing – finding strong companies that will grow in the future? If you are looking for a great combination of dividend and growth, check out my picks at Dividend Growth Rocks.

attributes.bio:
My name is Mike and I’m the author of The Dividend Guy Blog & The Dividend Monk along with the owner and portfolio manager here at Dividend Stocks Rock (DSR). I earned my bachelor degree in finance-marketing, own a CFP title along with an MBA in financial services. Besides being a passionate investor, I’m also happily married with three beautiful children. I started my online venture to educate people about investing and to be able to spend more time with my family.

I started my career in the financial industry back in 2003. I earned several promotions along with a good pile of diplomas. I had lots of fun working with clients in private banking for half a decade, but thought I could do more with my life.

In 2016, I decided to take a leap of faith and left everything behind to travel across North America and Central America with my family. We drove through nine countries and stayed three months in Costa Rica before returning home. This was an eye-opening adventure that led me in 2017 to quit my job in the financial industry and pursue my dream; helping others with their personal finance through my investing websites.

You just found the reason why I quit my suit & tie job!
